title: 112_s3491
content: The Act titled "Qualifying Renewable Chemical Production Tax Credit Act of 2012" provides a credit for the production of renewable chemicals under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Qualifying Renewable Chemical Production Tax Credit Act of 2012" offers a credit for producing renewable chemicals under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is $0.15 per pound of eligible content of renewable chemicals produced in a taxable year, with a limit set by the Secretary. Eligible content is defined as the biobased content percentage of the total organic carbon mass in the chemical. The term 'biobased content percentage' refers to the percentage of biobased content in a renewable chemical, determined using ASTM D6866 testing. A 'renewable chemical' is one produced in the US from renewable biomass and used for various applications like polymers and plastics. The term 'biobased content percentage' refers to the percentage of biobased content in a renewable chemical, determined using ASTM D6866 testing. A 'renewable chemical' is one produced in the US from renewable biomass and used for applications like polymers and plastics, not for food, feed, or fuel production. Exceptions include chemicals with less than 25% biobased content, over 10,000,000 pounds produced in 2000, not reliant on biomass conversion, or composed of renewable chemicals eligible for a credit. The term 'renewable biomass' is defined in the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, will establish a program to allocate credits under this section. The total amount of credits allocated shall not exceed $500,000,000. The program allocates credits to taxpayers, with a limit of $25,000,000 per taxpayer. Selection criteria include job creation in the US. The program allocates credits to taxpayers for renewable chemicals based on criteria such as reduced dependence on imported feedstocks, technological innovation, energy efficiency, and commercial viability. If the credit amount exceeds a certain limit, redistribution may occur. The program allocates credits to taxpayers for renewable chemicals based on specific criteria. If the credit amount exceeds a limit, redistribution may occur, and the Secretary must disclose the allocation details publicly. The Secretary may not allocate any credit amount under this section to any taxable year beginning more than 5 years after the enactment. The renewable chemicals production credit is now part of the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. The renewable chemicals production credit is now part of the general business credit under section 38 of the Code, with redesignated clauses and a new clause added. The production of renewable chemicals credit, under section 45S, applies to chemicals produced after the enactment date of the Act in taxable years ending after that date.
